text: We’re taken back to... SUPER: 1969. Five Years Earlier The height of innocence and bubblegum pop. It’s ladies ni at a popular college bar. Two frothy beers plunk down on table crowded with empties, where LIZ commiserates with h best friend JOANNA.
Why did you have to drag me to a college bar? I feel invisible here.
The best way to get over someone is to get under someone.
No guy wants to go with a single mom who works as a secretary.

Tonight you’re not a single mom, you're single. You’re not a secretary, you have a secretary. And how can you be invisible if that guy’s been staring at you all night? Liz glances across the way at someone who causes her to momentarily lose herself. We don’t see him yet -- we stay her. Because she just fell in love.
You are my candy girl... And you got me wanting you... Liz looks away. Takes a long pull on her beer.
He’s not staring at me, he’s staring at the blonde on the dance floor who’s not wearing a bra.
I think he’s coming over.

I think if I hear one more love song I’m going to puke. Liz gets up. Stumbles. She’s had a few. On her way to the jukebox, she fumbles coins from her pocket which roll awa As she curses to herself and crouches to find them, TWO F step up. The stranger opens his palm revealing a single coin. Liz rises to meet TED. Handsome. Dapper. A smile that turns strangers into friends. She has yet to look away fr his beautiful blue eyes. We have too. He has a clean cut, preppy look compared to all the longhairs.
It’s my last dime so we better make it a good one. In the background, Joanna checks out his ass. Gives Liz emphatic approval. Liz can’t find her voice.
I haven’t seen you here before.
It’s the first time I’ve been out since I moved to Seattle.
Explains the new car smell.
No, that’s just Utah.
That’s in Wyoming, right? Liz hides a smile. They flip through the selection cards.
So what do you do? Work? School? Race car driver? Liz glances at Joanna in the background. Tries out her li
I make heart valves.
I’m a lawyer. Ever hear of voir dire?
Is that Latin or are you slurring too? Ted bashfully laughs -- one of his endearing qualities.
Is it that obvious?
So what are you going to play for me, counselor? He pretends like he’s studying her.

Given it’s taken you this long to leave your seat, I’d say you’re probably ready to move. Since you needed four beers to get there, I suspect you’re usually too shy to dance. But you left it up to me, so you're willing to take a risk. And seeing as you spent the entire night crying to your girlfriend instead of noticing me noticing you, I’m guessing probably not a love song. Unless you’re feeling hopeful? This guy’s good.
How are you feeling? Ted inserts the coin. Punches a number.
Like we could both use some company. The opening pep of “Build Me Up Buttercup” by the Founda rile up the place. Liz wilts in shyness. Ted pulls her toward the dance floor.

What’s the matter? They don’t have dancing in Utah? What do they call folks from Utah anyway? Utonians? Utahites? Utahcrats? Liz considers him. His eyes. His ease. His ear-to-ear gri that’s as goofy as it is charming. There’s something abou him that’s magnetic. Liz downs the rest of her beer.
(hick voice) Utaaaaaaahns. They laugh and start dancing with complete and utter reck abandon. With the complete innocence of youth.
Why do you build me up...? Buttercup, baby, just to let me down... And mess me around... And then worst of all... After a while, Ted pulls Liz close. Feels more intimate:
What do you say we get outta here?
I don’t even know your name.
But you already feel like you've known me all your life.
How do you know that?
Because I feel the same. The electricity is undeniable. Each sizzling with desire, leans in to kiss her...
Wait. I don’t make heart valves.
(shrugs ) I’m not a lawyer. Then, as if the world disappears around them, they kiss.
Buttercup, don't break my heart...
They stumble out laughing, heading for Liz's car.
I’m applying to law school after I graduate -- if I ever finish my Chinese Studies major, that is.
Does that mean you speak Chinese?
Wo zai sho-hua.
What did you just say? Ted shrugs. They both laugh. Liz, clearly the drunker one misses the keyhole on her car.

(John Wayne impression) Now, listen here, pilgrim. A cowboy never lets a lassie drive drunk. Life is hard, but it’s harder if you’re stupid, and gettin’ behind that wheel is ri-god- damn-diculous. So hand ‘em here, or I’m gonna hafta frisk ya’. She teasingly hides her keys behind her back so he has to his arms around her to get them.
Ted’s VW BUG pulls over in a nice neighborhood.
Why are we stopping?
I wanna show you something.  HOLD ON the IDLING ENGINE of Ted’s Bug.
Ted and Liz stroll arm-in-arm through the upscale neighborhood, brown-bagging a bottle of wine, his coat ar her, comfortably close now.
Someday, when I’m a big-wig lawyer, I’m going to buy one of these houses.
There’s one I like, it’s big, with a brick chimney, and a view of the Puget Sound, not far from here.
I can see it already -- warm fires on cold Seattle nights, barbeques in the backyard with friends...
And a Mercedes in the driveway?

We should get a dog too! A big one that we can take on hikes with us. In fact, I can hear him barking now. Do you hear it? He makes her listen to the peaceful night breeze -- then BARKS really loud in her ear, scaring her half to death. They laugh and cuddle, the stars infinite and bright abov
They arrive at her front door. Ted waits expectantly but looks hesitant about inviting him in.
Guess I better get going. His disappointment is palpable. Liz is obviously conflict Then the front door OPENS, revealing a HIGH SCHOOL GIRL w her coat and backpack. Liz blushes, embarrassed.
Sorry to interrupt, but you said you'd be back two hours ago and I have school tomorrow.
Ted, this is Rachel. My sitter. (then) I understand if you want to go. Liz braces for rejection like she’s used to it.
Why on earth would I want to do that? Liz sighs with relief. INT. LIZ’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 6 Ted and Liz look in on her BABY, asleep in a crib.
Are you sure you don’t want to run?

Only if it’s after you. She smiles. They lay down on the bed, fully clothed. She puts her head on his chest and closes her eyes. They fall asleep together. Tender, sweet, and innocent. FADE TO BLACK. INT. LIZ’S BEDROOM - DAY 7 Sunlight floods the room. Liz is sprawled out in bed. As she wakes, the night’s events start to come back to her. looks over at the other side of the bed -- it’s empty. And so is the crib. Liz dashes out in a panic--

--as Ted turns around with a knife, chopping omelette veggies, cooing at Liz’s baby in a high chair. An idyllic domestic scene with brilliant morning light saturating everything. He flashes that smile again when he notices L
You looked so pretty sleeping, I didn’t want to-- She cuts him off with a kiss. This is what love looks lik

text: A collage of PHOTOS and HOME MOVIES that show the blossom of a spectacular relationship: Two beautiful young lovers a baby that’s growing up... holidays... vacations... birthdays... ticket stubs... a love we all hope for. The images start to come faster, the passage of time show the baby growing into a LITTLE GIRL, faster, faster still
A Volkswagen Bug sputters by dark houses in the pre-dawn hour. SUPER: Utah. Six Years Later.

Ted’s hunched over the wheel, driving the quiet, dark str His hair is longer, shaggier now. In his rearview, he notices another car tailing him, whic can only make as a silhouette behind the headlights. Ted gives it a little gas but the other car keeps pace. Suddenly the high beams flip on. He squints from the reflection in his rearview. Scared now, Ted punches it.
The Volkswagen Bug accelerates. The pursuing car keeps pa Ted burns through a stop sign. Only then do we realize that the pursuing car is a cop!
Red and blue lights play over Ted’s face. He curses and steers over.
Ted cuts the engine and gets out. He strolls to the rear his car as the cop pulls in behind. Ted shrugs, flashes t million dollar smile -- now becoming familiar to us.
(sheepishly) I guess I’m lost. 11. The cop is BOB HAYWARD, a no-nonsense highway patrol vete on the tail end of his shift. Smiles don’t work on him.
You ran two stop signs, son.
I do apologize, Officer, but I couldn’t make your car with the headlights in my eyes and, well, I guess I got spooked.
Got a license? Ted produces his ID.
What’s a kid from Seattle doing in Granger, Utah this time of morning?
I caught a late movie at the Redwood but I obviously missed the interstate on my way home. These subdivisions, man...
Must have been a good movie, drove all the way from Washington.
I live in Salt Lake now. I’ma law student at the University of Utah. Hayward pans his flashlight inside Ted’s car.

(small talk) My girlfriend lives in Seattle. I’m going to propose once I graduate. Right now, I’m just trying to save money for a ring so I'd really appreciate getting off without a ticket, if you can find the heart.
What’d you see tonight?  14 15 16 17 12.
The Towering Inferno. Hayward pans the flashlight back on Ted.
HANDCUFFS snap around Ted’s wrists. Hayward shuts Ted in the back of a squad car.
Ted laughs, shaking his head at the absurdity of events a Hayward removes items from a black canvas duffle bag...

It’s just junk I picked up around the house, I swear. Garbage bags... flashlight... gloves... rope... (NOTE: Additional items need to be shot; see end montage. “POSSESSION OF BURGLARY TOOLS,” reads the arrest report.
Ever been to the town of Murray?
Ted and seven doppelgangers file into a lineup facing the own reflections in a two-way mirror. Ted steps forward, turns profile, swallows hard.
Ted turns for a mug shot, eyes ringed with shock.
You are hereby charged with aggravated kidnapping and attempted criminal assault. The flash bulb POPS.
Ted stands for arraignment, face drained of color.
Trial is set for the twenty-third of February. (MORE )
You shall remain in the custody of the Salt Lake County Sheriff's Department. Bail is set at one hundred thousand dollars. The GAVEL-POUNDS.
Liz types at her desk. A FRAMED PICTURE of her and Ted caught in a moment of uncontrollable laughter beside.

Hey Liz, isn’t this your boyfriend? Liz's work neighbor JERRY -- unassuming, kinda shlubby -- leans over to show her a newspaper. What she sees stuns h She starts to feel uncomfortable when she notices coworke looking at her. (She’s the only woman who works here.)
Ted's lawyer JOHN O'CONNELL enters in his usual cowboy ha and boots. He’s tall, bearded, with overgrown black hair.
John, what the hell is going on?
Let’s start on November 8th, 1974.

If I can’t remember where I was on a random night one year ago, it’s because my memory does not improve with time. It’s safe to say what I was not doing, however. I was not having heart surgery, nor was I taking ballet lessons, nor was I in Mexico, nor was I abducting a complete stranger.
An alibi would be the best first step.
I don’t even know this woman! My heart goes out to her because that is a truly awful thing for anyone to have gone through, but she’s obviously mistaking me for someone else.  14.
The good news is there’s no physical evidence and eye witness testimony is precarious at best.
Why is this happening?
You remember anything about two girls disappearing at a lake last year in Seattle?
(searching) Yeah, I remember a police sketch of the suspect in the paper -- all my friends teased me about a resemblance. No one was serious, though.
Someone must have been because your name landed on a list. When the Utah police got wind of that, they started looking at you with more serious eyes because a similar thing has been happening here.
I have a girlfriend, who has a young daughter, both of whom I love dearly. I would never hurt a woman.

There are twelve hundred names on that list and last I checked, brown hair and blue eyes are hardly grounds for conviction. It’s an open and shut case, as far as I’m concerned. Let me do what I do best and in the end it’1ll be nothing more than a funny story you tell at cocktail parties. You’re posting tomorrow.
My bail’s a hundred grand.
For a boyscout with no priors? I knocked it down to fifteen.  20 21 22 15.
I don’t have fifteen.
Your pals in the Washington State governor's office passed a hat around. You think Utah’s top defense attorney works pro bono? Ted smiles. Finally good news.

INT. KITCHEN - LIZ’S HOUSE - DAY 20 Wine POURS into a glass. Liz anxiously bounces her knee a the table with the newspaper Jerry showed her laid out be her. She takes a big drink. Also at the table, her daughter MOLLY (now 8) draws a pic of a shark with crayons. The DOORBELL RINGS. Before Molly gets up--
Stay here.
Liz opens the door, revealing Ted holding a newspaper ove his head in the rain. As he takes her face in his hands t kiss her -- she slaps him.
Jesus, Liz! What was that for? Liz shows him the newspaper he was using as an umbrella. He’s mortified by the headline.
How many stop signs did you run?
We finally see the newspaper: “Seattle Man Arrested in Ut with TED’'S MUGSHOT. Picking up mid-argument:
You don’t actually believe this garbage, do you? (MORE )
For chrissakes, Liz, I don’t know if I should be offended or rolling on the floor laughing.
It’s in all the papers, Ted.
That must make it true then. In six years, have I ever laid a hand on you? When we went shopping for ski racks and that lady got her purse snatched, what did I do? What did I do, Liz?!
You ran him down.
(re: newspaper) Is that the behavior of a man who does this? Jesus, Liz. You wanna search my bags too? Liz breaks down crying.
(softening) Come here, stupid. Ted pulls her into a hug.

I didn’t tell you because I didn’t want you to freak out. It’s not exactly something to say over the phone. And, honestly, I was embarrassed. It’s all a big misunderstanding. I know it’s hard being apart, but we only have four semesters standing between us and our place on the Sound with a Mercedes and a dog, just like we always dreamed. The moment's interrupted when Molly charges in, excited t see Ted.
Ted!
Monkey! I missed you so much!  23 Ted scoops her up, slings her over his shoulder, her up and down.
Sack o’ potatoes! Sack o’ potatoes! Molly laughs hysterically. It’s their game.
(to Molly) I missed you so much, monkey. What do you say we get cheeseburgers and root beer floats tonight, and be big fatsoes?
Can we go to the Pepper Pod, Mom? Can we, can we, can we?
Yeah, can we, Mommy? Liz considers Ted and Molly. A precious sight.
(reassuring, to Liz) It’s just a big misunderstanding. I’ve got it all under control. Liz finally softens. She believes him.
and bounces 23 Ted and Liz talk over cheeseburgers and fries while Molly colors with crayons on butcher paper.
You can ask me anything you want.
Did you do it, Ted?
No, monkey. And I hired the best defense attorney in Utah and he says this case has no legs. It’s all going to be thrown out.
Why did she pick you out of the lineup?  18.

My lawyer found out the police showed her my picture beforehand -- twice. So of course I looked familiar to her. But that’s not the worst part. What happened in Utah wasn’t dumb luck, Liz. The police already had my name. Someone gave it to them.
(beat) Who would do that to you?

I’m sure I made a few enemies the year I worked the Rockefeller campaign, but that was politics. This is personal. It doesn’t add up, Liz. The traffic stop, sure -- that was wrong place, wrong time -- but the way it escalated? What the hell are “burglary tools” anyways? There was nothing in my car you wouldn't also find in your own house right now. Only reason it was in there was because I was cleaning up before your visit. Now, suddenly I’m on trial, it’s in all the papers, and my name’s been smeared before I even had a chance to clear it. (looks past her) See that car over there? It’s been following me since I got back. (leans in) I_think I’m being set up. A sense of paranoia builds as Liz turns to look... until she’s startled by--
Done! Molly shows them a CRAYON SHARK DRAWING she just did.
It’s a thresher shark. They have a tail as long as their whole body.
They do?! How did you get so smart, monkey?  24 19.
I read a lot. Ted tickles Molly, as Liz looks at the DARK SEDAN out the window Ted was referring to. She looks worried for Ted. Over the din of a cocktail reception:
Hold on to this one, honey. He’1l be governor himself one day.
A Republican fundraiser. ROSS DAVIS, Chairman of the WA State Republican Party, slings his arm around Ted, boasti to Liz.
This man single-handedly got Dan Evans re-elected. Ted secretly rolls his eyes at Liz. He excuses himself to steal away with Liz for a moment.
I know how you hate these things so I won’t be completely torn up if you want to leave.
I’m fine.
Great. Then you won’t mind if I do?
These people raised money for your defense!
And I’m grateful, but c’mon, I’ve had yawns more exciting than this.
We do need to get the sitter home by ten, but I thought I was dropping you at the law library to get ready for trial?
Welcome home, stranger.  20. They're interrupted by a tall woman in thick, tinted glas who hugs Ted. Pretty in a boyish way, her name is CAROLE BOONE.
Carole Ann! My goodness. How are you? Have you met my girlfriend Liz? (to Liz) Carole Ann and I worked together at DES in Olympia years ago. (to Carole Ann) How's your son?
He just turned eight.
Oh, that’s my daughter’s age. (joking) Maybe they’1l date.
(excusing himself) Will you excuse us a second, Carole Ann? Ted walks Liz to the exit.
How will you get to the library?

I just squeezed fifteen grand out of the Republican Party, I’m sure I can hitch a ride. He pretends to bite her nose. Liz smiles. Completely in love. As she exits, Ted sees her off... then Carole Ann moseys over next to him.
She seems great.
She's the best. Liz is my rock.
Everything's going to be okay, you know. The young Republican who worked the suicide prevention hotline? How many lives have you saved, for godsakes? (MORE )

Whoever this woman accusing you is, I’m sure she’s just mixing you up with another handsome stranger. There’s an awkward pause. Ted smiles bashfully. Carole An has a noticeable spark in her eye for Ted.
If you need anything -- anything at all... Ted blushes, registers the roaring sexual tension.

Ted enters the law library. All the girls turn their head one by one, watching him pass. One girl watches him from over her NEWSPAPER. Ted sends them all friendly smiles an winks, loving every second.

Liz brushes her teeth before bed, as her eyes land on TED SUITCASE. She goes to it, thinks for a beat, then looks through clothes, toiletries, check book, etc. Nothing out the ordinary. She smells his clothes. Off her ambiguous look...

Ted browses legal tomes. An ATTRACTIVE GIRL catches his e through the HORIZONTAL GAP in the bookshelf. They can onl see each other’s EYES. She smiles at him. Ted smiles back. Moments later, she nudges a book from he side, JUTTING OUT the opposing book on Ted’s side. Ted debates, then returns a nudge of his own. They repeat this exchange, a flirtation like PIANO KEYS d the shelf, until they get to the end where there are no m books and they finally see each other’s faces. They’re both startled by a SECURITY GUARD...
Sir, will you come with me please? ANGLE ON -- the girl reading the newspaper, watching Ted escorted out, as the camera lands on TED’S MUGSHOT.  29 30 22.
Ted protests as he’s escorted out.
I am an alumnus of this school!
Look, buddy, you seem like a nice guy, but you’re making the girls nervous.

What do they think I’m going to do, knock ‘em over the head and attack ‘em in the bookstacks? The guard shuts the door on Ted. Fuming, Ted spots a SIMI DARK SEDAN across the street. The same one, or different? We can’t tell. He marches up to it. Bangs on the window.
Hey! Who are you? I know you’re following me! The car starts up and drives away.
Who sent you?! As it speeds off into the darkness, Ted fills with anger. Paranoia. Fear. He stands in the quiet night... alone.
Dead of night. Liz is fast asleep. She stirs, squints her eyes open... and realizes SOMEONE’s sitting next to her U
THE SHEETS with a LIGHT ON. She screams! Jumps up! Ted startles out from under the sheets. Flashlight in his hand. Surprised by Liz’s reaction.
(re: flashlight) What are you doing? Ted shows her a paperback he’s reading. Astute viewers ma notice it’s Capote’s In Cold Blood.
Reading.  31 23.
With a flashlight under the sheets?
I didn’t want to wake you. They realize the absurdity of the situation and break int laughter. As Liz starts to catch her breath...
I think we should get married. Liz loses her breath completely.

Two skiers zzzzZZZZOOOOOOMMMM past in a blur. Ted and Liz cut down a daunting double black diamond. Liz pulls ahead Ted crouches lower. Gains ground. Neck and neck, fast approaching the finish... ...Liz wins by a hair! She taunts him in celebration. He tackles her in the snow and kisses her
Ted and Liz meet O’Connell outside the courtroom on their in. Ted’s clean shaven in a light blue/gray suit, white shirt, and bow tie -- and noticeably tanner.
Where'd you fly in from, Barbados?
Liz and I hit the slopes yesterday. We're engaged! Once we win this thing, I might just make you my best man.
(re: O’Connell’s beard) You'll have to shave for our wedding photos, of course. Won't you scare the jury with that thing?
If we had one. We waived it. Local press all but convicted him so an impartial jury was hard to find.  33 24.
(to Ted) You waived the jury? Shouldn't we have talked about this?
It’s a good thing, Liz.
The whole case hinges on eyewitness testimony which is notoriously unreliable, but the most likely thing for a jury to convict on.
That's why we’re putting it all in the hands of the judge.
Hanson’s a fair-minded guy with a reputation for controversial acquittals. I went to school with the sonofabitch.
(to O’Connell) You're really going to shave for the wedding?
Blow me.
JUDGE HANSON presides over a high-ceilinged courtroom. No jury in the box. Ted finds Liz in the sparse gallery. Sends her a wink as prosecutor DAVID YOCOM delivers his opening statement.

Your Honor, November 8th, 1974 may have been just another rainy night for most of Murray, Utah, but it was a life-altering tornado of horror for one woman in particular. She was shopping for a birthday gift at the Fashion Place Shopping Mall when she was approached by a man posing as a police officer. He flashed a badge and asked her to come with him. (MORE )

As the daughter of a police officer, she felt foolish to question his authority, so she followed him to the parking lot where he led her to what he claimed to be an unmarked police vehicle. When he drove in the opposite direction of the police department, she knew she was in trouble. When he slapped a handcuff around her wrist, she knew she was in danger. Fortunately, before he could latch the other, she twisted free and fled for her life. (beat) Then he pursued her with a crowbar. The courtroom suddenly drops a few degrees.
CAROL DARONCH, a soft-featured, 19-year old, strawberry blonde girl, relives the pain of that night.

I was kicking him, and screaming. He held a small black gun to my head and said, “If you don’t stop screaming, I’m going to kill you. I'll blow your brains out.” I fell backward out of his car, and I ran as fast as I could.
As best you recall, Carol, is that man present in court today?
Yes.
Where is he seated? She timidly looks toward Ted, who looks equally sympathet and incredulous. Liz sends him support from the gallery.
Let the record show the identification of the defendant. No further questions, Your Honor. Ted's lawyer JOHN O'CONNELL rises in his usual cowboy hat boots. He’s out for blood.  26.
Ms. DaRonch, it is your testimony now that you did scratch this man?
All my fingernails were broken.
Yet in the preliminary hearing Mr. Yocom asked, “Do you recall ever scratching him with those fingernails?” and you answered, “No.” Do you have an explanation for that?
No.
In fact, the officers on November 8th asked if you remembered if you hurt the man in any way, and you told them no then too, didn’t you?
I don’t remember.
You also said he had a mustache. But shortly after the incident you said he didn’t. Then sometime later you decided he did again?
Yes.
When did you make that decision?
Right after I decided that he didn’t have one.
Ms. DaRonch, had the police shown you any pictures of the defendant prior to your identification of him at the October 2nd lineup?
Yes.  27.

You did in fact pick his picture out of a pile. But when asked why you chose his picture specifically, you stated, “It looks something like him, but I really couldn't say for sure.” DaRonch looks down. Tears up.
Tell me, Ms. DaRonch. If you were unsure of your identification then, ten months after the incident, what makes you so sure of it now, nearly a_year and a half later? DaRonch is at a complete loss.
Now Ted’s on the witness stand -- dapper, relaxed, and confident. Liz sends him encouragement from the gallery.
Do you remember the night of August 16th, 1975?
(smiles) Isn’t that why we’re all here? A few laughs in the courtroom. Not even a grin from Yocom
You were arrested for fleeing an officer.
Objection, Your Honor.
You were arrested for evading an officer.
Objection.
How about rabbited?
Fine. Why did you “rabbit” from Officer Hayward?  28.
The truth?
Only that which you swore to tell in whole and nothing but.
(matter-of-factly) I was smoking marijuana. O'Connell nearly leaps out of his chair.
Objection! Your Honor, I’d like to request a five minute conference with my cli--

It’s okay, John. (to Yocom) I was smoking grass and had to air out the car. I’m only grateful the officer didn’t notice me flick it out the window or he’d have stuck me with littering too and then I'd really be up a creek. Chuckles in the court. 0O’Connell’s about to faint.
But you withheld this detail from your arresting officer, and apparently even your own attorney.
I was embarrassed.

That may be, sir, but at the end of the day a lie is a lie. Ted sheepishly grins, the gravity of his candor sinking i 35 INT. JOHN O’CONNELL’S OFFICE - DAY 35 O'Connell barges in, followed by Ted and Liz.
Stoned?!
Now, John, let’s just relax here.  29.
Do you realize you just took a dump on our entire defense? The game plan was keep your mouth shut and stick to the script.
I won't sit there like a stuffed shirt while the state distorts all the facts. They’re railroading me!
Your grandstanding took precedence over basic strategy and now it’s all but done you in.
People respect honesty. I think it was courageous. The truth is always the way to go.
In court, truth is what you leave out -- especially when it’s a liability.
It’s going to turn out fine. I know it. I have a feeling.
It’s in the judge’s hands now. All we can do is hope. Liz takes Ted’s hand as a melancholy falls over the room.
Ted and Liz walk up to a dog pound.
Are you sure you want to do this now?
If not now, when? Just because we don’t have our house on the Sound, doesn’t mean we can’t look for the dog... Ted opens the door for Liz.  36 37 30.
Ted and Liz look at DOGS IN CAGES.
(re: a specific dog) What about this guy? He looks like a good roommate. Ted doesn’t respond -- he’s distracted by all these anima in cages. An ominous a reminder of his very possible futu
Earth to Ted...
He’s right. This thing should have been a slam dunk. Why couldn’t I just keep my mouth shut?
If you could do that we never would have met. Her attempt to lighten the mood falls flat. She notices Ted’s hand shaking. She takes it in hers. Knows she needs to be the strong one now.
No matter what happens, promise you won't leave me, Liz. I don’t know what I'd do without you.
I would never. The BARKING in the background gets louder and more primal He stares them down.

Warm, intimate tones. Close, intimate SHOTS: A half-empty bottle of tequila. A salt shaker. Chewed up limes. A turntable playing a LOVE SONG. Ted’s pet plant “FERN.” Ted and Liz fool around -- drunk, giggling, undressing ea other in a romantically playful way. As it starts to get heavy -- he GRABS her by the hair. Sh gasps in exhilaration. It’s hot. Two beautiful people in passionate throes. Ted throws her on the bed. His eyes fix in a primal stare Liz stares back in a hot combination of fear and desire..  38 39 31. As Ted goes in for the kill. INT. TED’S APARTMENT - LATER 38 Ted and Liz catch their breath in twisted sheets, sharing joint, looking like they just got fucked by a tornado.
What was that?
“Last Night of Freedom” sex? She shoots him a look.
Too soon.
Restless murmurs die down to eerie silence. Judge Hanson looks out over the courtroom. Ted and Liz make flirty eye from a distance. Last night still on their minds.

After an agonizing weekend pondering the arguments presented in this courtroom, and by the power vested in me as both judge and jury, I hereby find the defendant guilty of aggravated kidnapping beyond a reasonable doubt. Liz's blood runs cold. Her entire world flipped upside do
You will be remanded to the Utah State Prison to await sentencing. This court is adjourned. CLACK! A court deputy handcuffs Ted, shell-shocked. Liz moves toward him but another deputy holds her back.
(crying) Ted...
